Description: The upper part of an object of fine marlware pottery, reconstructed from fragments. It consists of a cylindrical spout at the top, surrounded by a flared collar, with the convex-sided body of the vessel below. Parts of the rim around the collar are missing. The function is unclear, but it has been interpreted as a food-cover with an open spout to allow steam to escape.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", east annex (G), Findspot 28, under level of chamber 18.
Curator's comments: The suggestion of a food-cover is from Petrie, who notes a similar object, kept in Cairo, which incorporated a perforated cylindrical tube. See Petrie 1888, p. 65 § 61. The Findspot number 28 has been scratched into the object.
Bibliographic references: Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.95, p.98, p.111, p.198, pl.40, p.220, pl.62)
Acquisition notes: The item came to the Museum in 1887 but was kept with unregistered material in the Greek and Roman Department. Brought to the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan in 2009.
